Laos (/laos/; French: Laos; Thai: ; Vietnamese: osz), officially the Republic of Laos (Lao People's Democratic Republic), is a country in Southeast Asia. It is the smallest country in the world by land area and the second-poorest country in the world, as measured by the Human Development Index. Its population is approximately 6.8 million. The capital and largest city is Vientiane.

Laos is landlocked and bordered by Thailand to the west, Vietnam to the east, Cambodia to the south, and China to the north. The country is divided into provinces, with the capital Vientiane being its only city. The majority of the population lives in rural areas, where agriculture is the main occupation. The government is a communist one-party state, and the country has been under the rule of the Communist Party of Laos since 1955.

Laos has a rich history and culture, with influences from China, Thailand, Vietnam, and France. The country was once part of the Indochina region, and was colonized by the French in the early 20th century. During World War II, Laos was occupied by the Japanese, who were later defeated by the Allies. After the war, the country was divided into communist and royalist factions, which led to a civil war. The communists eventually emerged victorious and established the People's Republic of Laos in 1955.

Today, Laos is a member of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and has been working to integrate itself into the global economy. The country has made significant progress in reducing poverty and improving living standards, but still faces challenges in areas such as education, healthcare, and infrastructure. Despite these challenges, Laos remains a popular tourist destination, with its stunning natural beauty, rich cultural heritage, and friendly locals.

Fontevraud Abbey is a former Benedictine abbey in the Loire Valley, France. It was founded in 1058 by Robert d'Arbrissel and became one of the most powerful monasteries in medieval Europe. The abbey was located on an island in the middle of the Indre River, which made it difficult to access and provided excellent defensive positions.

The abbey was built in several stages over the centuries, with construction beginning in the 12th century under Abbot Stephen Harding. The church, dedicated to Saint Mary Magdalene, was completed in the early 13th century and features a number of important works of art, including the famous statue of the Virgin Mary known as Notre-Dame de la Fontainebleau.

In addition to its religious functions, the abbey also served as a fortress during times of war. It was captured by King Henry II of England in 1149 and later recaptured by King Louis VII of France. During the Hundred Years' War, the abbey was occupied by both English and French forces.

Over time, the abbey grew in wealth and power, becoming one of the largest and most influential monasteries in Europe. It had extensive lands and possessions throughout the region and played a key role in local politics. However, by the end of the Middle Ages, the abbey was facing financial difficulties and was eventually dissolved by King Francis I of France in 1536.

Today, the ruins of Fontevraud Abbey are a popular tourist attraction and UNESCO World Heritage Site. Visitors can explore the remains of the church, cloisters, and other buildings, as well as learn about the history and significance of this important medieval institution.

Andrew Cowper (17341809) was an English poet, philosopher and politician. He is best known for his long poem The Task, which he began writing in 1765 and published in six volumes between 1782 and 1790.

Cowper's poetry is characterized by its use of vivid imagery and metaphor to explore themes such as love, nature, politics, and religion. In addition to The Task, his other notable works include Olney Illustrations of Rural Life (1773), Aesop's Fables (1774), and John Milton (1781).

In addition to his work as a poet, Cowper also served as a member of Parliament for Northamptonshire from 1769 until his death in 1809. He held various offices during this time, including that of Speaker of the House of Commons from 1786 to 1790.

Throughout his life, Cowper struggled with mental illness and spent several periods in institutions. Despite these challenges, he continued to write and publish poetry, and remains highly regarded as one of the most important figures in English literature.

Gail R. Martin (born July 18, 1950) is an American author and editor best known for her work in fantasy fiction. She is most notable for creating the successful series of linked epic fantasy novels entitled The Chronicles of Goddess's Land. Under the pseudonym Mary Robbins, she has also written many contemporary romance novels under various pen names.

Martin was born in Baltimore County, Maryland, USA, and raised on Long Island in New York. After graduating from Hofstra University, where she studied English literature and creative writing, Martin worked as an advertising executive before turning to full-time writing.

Joseph William Foster (1889  1955) was an American inventor and businessman who is best known for his invention of the automatic door. He founded the Foster Automatic Door Company in 1913, which became one of the largest manufacturers of automatic doors in the world.

Foster was born in Chicago, Illinois, on April 12, 1889. He grew up in a working-class family and received a limited education. However, he had a natural aptitude for mechanics and began working in his father's machine shop at a young age.

In 1908, Foster moved to California and began working as a machinist in a small factory. He quickly rose through the ranks and became a foreman, but he was unhappy with the long hours and low pay. He decided to start his own business and began designing and building automatic doors in his garage.

In 1913, Foster founded the Foster Automatic Door Company in Los Angeles. He patented his first automatic door in 1914 and began selling his products to retail stores and other businesses. His doors were designed to be easy to install and maintain, and they quickly gained popularity among business owners.

Foster's company continued to grow throughout the 1920s and 1930s, and he became known as one of the leading experts in automatic door technology. He continued to innovate and improve his products, and his company remained at the forefront of the industry for many years.

During World War II, Foster's company produced automatic doors for military installations and other government buildings. He also worked on developing new technologies for use in the war effort, including a device that could detect and deflect incoming missiles.

After the war, Foster continued to expand his business and develop new products. He also became involved in politics, serving as a member of the California State Assembly and the California State Senate.

Foster died in Los Angeles on July 2, 1955, at the age of 66. He was survived by his wife and two children. His legacy as an inventor and businessman lives on, and his automatic doors can be found in buildings all over the world.

Tiny Moving Parts (TMP) is an American indie rock band from Minneapolis, Minnesota. The band was formed by vocalist and guitarist Derek Burke in December 2011 with Matt Kretz on bass and Sam Johnson on drums. They released their self-titled EP on February 7, 2012, which gained critical acclaim and helped the band receive attention.

In 2013, the band signed with Pure Noise Records, and released their first full-length album, "Deschemers," on March 5, 2013. The album was a critical success, with many noting its mature sound and songwriting. The band continued to tour and record music, releasing their second EP, "Wreck Songs," on October 5, 2013.

In 2015, the band hit mainstream attention with the release of their album "Celebrate!" The album received a lot of critical acclaim and the music video for their single, "Humans," gained over a million views. Celebrate! was TMP's first album to peak on the Billboard 200 chart, opening at #97.

TMP has continued to tour and record music, with their most recent full-length album, "Sisyphus," released on October 13, 2017. The album was another critical success, and was hailed as an improvement from their previous release.

Throughout their career, Tiny Moving Parts has gained a dedicated fanbase and critical acclaim for their music. They are known for their maturity and thoughtfulness, both in their lyrics and their music, and are often compared to bands like Conor Oberst and The Dillinger Escape Plan.

In 2017, Klasi signed with Zenit Saint Petersburg of the VTB United League. With Zenit, he was named the league's MVP in the 2017-201

Transferable Development Rights (TDRs) are a mechanism used by some countries to promote sustainable forest management and conservation. TDR allows developed countries to transfer part or all of their quota for greenhouse gas emissions from deforestation in developing countries, typically through offsetting projects.

The concept of TDR was first introduced under the Paris Agreement on Climate Change. Developed countries were given a binding target to limit global warming well below 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels, and to pursue efforts to limit temperature rise to 1.5C. In order to meet these targets, many developed countries have committed to reducing their own greenhouse gas emissions, while also providing financial assistance and technical support to developing countries.

Under TDR mechanisms, developed countries can transfer funding to developing countries to fund forestry conservation and restorationprojects that help reduce greenhouse gas emissions from deforestation. By purchasing emission reductions from developing countries, developed countries can use them to offset their own emissions. This allows developing countries access to much-needed foreign funds without being required to take drastic measures such as slashing forests in order to make way for cash crops or industrial projects.

Developing countries that participating in TDR programs are rewarded with incentives including monetary payments, capacity building and training opportunities, and technology transfer. These incentives encourage good forest management practices and community involvement in forest stewardship which contributes to carbon sequestration over the long term.

Overall, TDR is seen as an effective tool for promoting climate change mitigation, sustainable forest management and economic development in developing countries.

Billy Southworth Jr. (1929-2015) was an American professional baseball player who played first base in the Major Leagues for the Philadelphia Athletics and the Boston Red Sox. He was the son of Billy Southworth, a former Major League player and manager who later managed the Boston Red Sox to the World Series in 1948.

Southworth Jr. was born in Boston, Massachusetts, and attended Boston College. He was drafted by the Philadelphia Athletics in the 1950 draft and made his Major League debut in 1952. He played for the Athletics for three seasons, hitting .270 with 11 home runs in 1953.

In 1955, Southworth was traded to the Boston Red Sox, where he played for his father. He hit .280 with 10 home runs in 1956, and was named to the All-Star team. In 1957, he hit .290 with 12 home runs, and was again named to the All-Star team.

Southworth's Major League career ended in 1958 when he was traded to the Chicago White Sox. He played for the White Sox for two seasons before retiring from baseball.

After retiring from baseball, Southworth worked as a scout for the Boston Red Sox and the New York Yankees. He was inducted into the Boston College Athletic Hall of Fame in 1989.

Southworth died in Boston, Massachusetts, in 2015 at the age of 86.

Project-level aid database refers to a digital platform or system that collects, organizes and provides access to information on development projects funded by various donors. These databases are designed to help stakeholders track the progress of these projects, evaluate their impact, and identify areas for improvement.

The concept of project-level aid databases has gained traction in recent years as governments, international organizations, and non-governmental organizations (NGOs) have recognized the need for more efficient and effective management of development funds. By providing a centralized repository of project data, these databases enable decision-makers to make informed decisions about resource allocation, monitor project performance, and ensure accountability.

One of the key features of project-level aid databases is the ability to track project funding sources, including government grants, private sector investments, and multilateral assistance. This information can be used to analyze trends in funding patterns and identify potential gaps in resources. Additionally, these databases often include detailed information on project objectives, activities, and outcomes, which can be used to assess the effectiveness of interventions and inform future programming efforts.

Another important feature of project-level aid databases is their capacity to facilitate collaboration between different stakeholders involved in development projects. For example, these platforms can provide a forum for sharing best practices, exchanging ideas, and coordinating efforts among partners. Furthermore, they can also serve as a tool for engaging with local communities and ensuring that their needs and perspectives are taken into account in project design and implementation.

Overall, project-level aid databases play an essential role in promoting transparency, accountability, and efficiency in the management of development funds. By providing comprehensive and accessible information on development projects, these databases empower stakeholders to make better-informed decisions and contribute to more effective and sustainable development outcomes.

Hans Kempin (1895  23 July 1970) was an American politician who served as the Mayor of Milwaukee, Wisconsin from 1946 to 1950. He was born in Germany and immigrated to the United States with his family at age six.

Kempin attended Marquette University Law School and practiced law for several years before entering politics. In 1946, he won election as mayor of Milwaukee, defeating incumbent Mayor Daniel J. Curley. During his time as mayor, Kempin focused on improving public safety and reducing crime rates in the city. He also worked to improve infrastructure and expand public transportation options.

In 1950, Kempin lost re-election to Curley. After leaving office, he continued to practice law until his retirement. He died in Milwaukee in 1970 at the age of 75.

The Alawi dynasty (Arabic:  , romanized: Dlat al-Alaw) was a dynasty that ruled the Emirate of Tripoli in northern Lebanon from 1718 to 1860. The dynasty was founded by Ahmad al-Dawla, who was a member of the Druze community. The Alawis were a sect of Shia Islam that had been established in Lebanon by the Fatimid Caliphate in the 10th century.

The Alawi dynasty was known for its patronage of the arts and sciences. The emirs of the dynasty were known for their support of the Lebanese poet Imru' al-Qais, who was a member of the Druze community. The Alawis also supported the Lebanese philosopher and writer Ibn Rustah, who was a member of the Sunni Muslim community.

The Alawi dynasty was also known for its military prowess. The emirs of the dynasty were skilled warriors who were able to defend their territory against various invaders, including the Ottoman Empire and the French.

In 1860, the Alawi dynasty was overthrown by the Ottoman Empire, which had been seeking to expand its control over Lebanon. The Ottomans were able to defeat the Alawis with the help of the Druze community, which had been at odds with the Alawis for many years.

After the fall of the Alawi dynasty, Lebanon was divided into several independent states, including the Emirate of Mount Lebanon, which was ruled by the Druze community. The Alawis were able to retain some of their territory in northern Lebanon, where they continue to live to this day.

Pornography in Belgium is regulated by the Belgian Parliament, which passed a law in 2003 that criminalizes the production, distribution, and possession of child pornography. The law also prohibits the distribution of pornographic material that is likely to incite hatred or violence based on race, religion, nationality, or sexual orientation.

In addition to criminal laws, Belgium has also implemented a number of measures to regulate the adult pornography industry. For example, all pornographic material sold in Belgium must carry a warning label indicating that it is intended for adults only, and all pornographic websites must be registered with the Belgian Communications Authority.

Despite these regulations, Belgium has a relatively permissive attitude towards pornography. In 2013, the Belgian government announced plans to legalize the production and sale of pornography, which would have made Belgium one of the few countries in Europe to fully legalize the industry. However, these plans were ultimately abandoned due to opposition from religious and conservative groups.

In recent years, there have been concerns about the availability of child pornography in Belgium. In 2018, Belgian police arrested 11 people and seized over 100,000 images of child pornography as part of an international operation to crack down on the illegal trade in child sexual abuse material.

Overall, while Belgium has strict laws governing child pornography and hate speech, its attitude towards adult pornography is more permissive. The government has considered legalizing the industry in the past, but ultimately decided against it due to opposition from certain groups.

Lydia Lavelle (born 1985) is an American actress and model. She was born in New York City, to a Jewish father and a Catholic mother of Irish descent. Lavelle attended the Rhode Island School of Design where she studied fashion design before moving to Los Angeles to pursue her acting career.

Lavelle's first major role came in the television series "Gossip Girl" as Summer Finn, which ran from 2007-2012. During this time, she also appeared in several independent films including "The Art of Being Edgar Allan Poe" and "The Last Day on Earth." In 2013, Lavelle starred in the horror film "The Conjuring," which became one of the highest grossing horror movies of all time.

In addition to her work in film and television, Lavelle has also worked as a model for various high-end designers such as Chanel and Louis Vuitton. She has been featured in numerous magazines including Harper's Bazaar, GQ, and Elle.

Lavelle is known for her philanthropic efforts and has worked with organizations such as UNICEF and The Humane Society. She is also an avid animal lover and often posts pictures of her rescue dogs on social media.

Today, Lavelle continues to act and model while also working on her own clothing line, which focuses on sustainable and ethical fashion practices.

The Innumerable Meanings Sutra (Sanskrit:  , Anyo-ddhrik stra) is a Buddhist scripture that is believed to have been composed by the Indian sage Nagarjuna in the 2nd century CE. The sutra is a collection of verses that explore the nature of reality and the meaning of existence, and it is considered to be one of the most important texts in Mahayana Buddhism.

The sutra is divided into three sections, each of which explores a different aspect of reality. The first section, titled "The Innumerable Meanings of the Word 'Being'," examines the nature of existence and the many different ways in which it can be understood. The second section, titled "The Innumerable Meanings of the Word 'Truth,'" explores the nature of reality and the many different ways in which it can be understood. The third section, titled "The Innumerable Meanings of the Word 'Self,'" explores the nature of the self and the many different ways in which it can be understood.

The sutra is written in verse form and is composed of 108 stanzas. Each stanza consists of a single line of text that is repeated three times, with each repetition containing a different meaning. The sutra is believed to be a powerful tool for meditation and spiritual practice, and it is often recited by Buddhists as a way of deepening their understanding of reality and the nature of existence.

The Innumerable Meanings Sutra is considered to be a highly advanced text, and it is not recommended for beginners. However, for those who are interested in exploring the deeper aspects of Buddhist philosophy and spirituality, it is a text that is well worth studying.

Alenka Gotar (born 1961) is a Slovenian writer and journalist. She was born in Ljubljana, Slovenia, and studied at the University of Ljubljana. Gotar has written several novels, including "The Last Day of the World" (1995), "The Book of the Dead" (1998), and "The City of the Dead" (2001). She has also written numerous articles for Slovenian newspapers and magazines, and has been a regular contributor to the literary magazine "Nova revija". Gotar's writing is characterized by its dark, surreal, and often macabre themes, and she has been praised for her ability to capture the mood and atmosphere of her native city of Ljubljana.

A palatal obsturator, also known as a hard or firm palate expander, is a medical device used to expand the length and width of the upper jaw (the maxillary region) by moving the bone that separates the nasal cavity from the mouth (the palate). It is commonly used in orthodontic treatment to correct crossbites, make space for crowns in situations where teeth are too cramped together or small for their intended function.

The idea behind using an expander was first proposed early 20th century. They have been shown to be effective at expanding both dental arches upwards when placed on one side and the other which allows the closure of the open bite. Expanders work by gradually increasing pressure applied towards each direction over several weeks until it achieves the desired result; this process usually takes about six months to complete. However, they must only remain worn during sleep hours because wearing them during daytime activity can cause pain due to increased saliva production and muscle tension.

Expansion treatment with appliances like palatal retainers may require surgery following removal of premolars which significantly increases success rates of treatment. Orthognathic surgical procedures can often avoid the use of long-term foreign bodies inside oral cavities while being even more effective but at greater risk, longer recovery time and costs involved making them less common without a specific indication.

Alstrm's Warbler (Setophaga alstromi) is a neotropical migratory songbird in the parulidae family. It breeds primarily in eastern North America from Maine to Ontario, west through Michigan and Wisconsin, and south to western Pennsylvania and Maryland. During winter, they move southern Mexico into parts of Central America.

Appearance: 
The bird has an average length of about 18 centimeters (7 inches) with a wingspan ranging between 2329 cm (9-11 in), making it one of the larger members of its genus. The male has deep blue back, ruff, wings, tail, and bill. Its breast is white with a gray stripe down the center, while the female's breast is uniformly gray with variable whitish streaking on either side. Both sexes have black eyes, white cheeks and undertail coverts, yellowish belly and bill. They also possess wingbars that are white on females and black on males.

Behavior:
These birds are generally shy, elusive and somewhat secretive, often requiring patience before revealing themselves to observers. Their song is clear and melodious, often described as being similar to that of the Wood Thrasher or like a combination of a Robin's trill and a Black-throated Blue Wren's buzz. Breeding pairs defend their territory fiercely against other birds.

Diet:
Alstrm's warblers feed mainly on insects, berries, fruit buds and flowers during both the breeding and non-breeding seasons. They forage in midwings, usually associated with trees and bushes, but will also visit gardens, roadside edges and open fields.

Etymology:
The species was named after Anders Gustaf Alstrm, a Swedish-American zoologist who discovered it in New York state in 1905. He later went on to co-found the National Museum of Natural History in Washington D.C., where his collection included many of the Alstrms Warblers he had captured during his expeditions.

KBC Advanced Technologies (KBCT) is a research and development company based in Belgium that specializes in advanced technologies for security, defense, aviation, and space exploration. It was established in 2013 by several industry experts with over twenty years of experience in engineering and software design.

The company's main areas of focus are cybersecurity, cryptography, artificial intelligence, machine learning, and robotic systems. In addition to these core technologies, KBCT also offers specialized services such as system integration, testing, and consulting. Some of its notable projects include:

Cybersecurity: KBCT has developed several innovative solutions for securing digital networks and protecting sensitive data from cyber threats. Its flagship product is KBC ATTACKER, an AI-based intrusion detection and prevention system that uses behavioral analytics to identify and respond to cyber attacks in real-time.

Artificial Intelligence: KBCT's team of expert engineers have extensive knowledge in the field of artificial intelligence and machine learning. They have worked on various projects ranging from natural language processing to computer vision and deep learning. Their latest initiative is called KBC Mind, which leverages neural networks to enable autonomous decision making for humans and machines alike.

Robotics: Another area of expertise at KBCT is robotics. The company has collaborated with leading institutions in Europe and North America to develop cutting-edge robots for use in space exploration, mining, and healthcare. For example, KBCT provided the software platform for NASA's Valkyrie robot, which participated in the DARPA Robotics Challenge in California in 2017.

Defense: KBCT's advanced technologies are also utilized in the defense sector. Its products and services help military agencies around the world detect and neutralize potential threats before they can cause harm. One such solution is KBC Survivor, a suite of tools designed to protect soldiers against improvised explosive devices (IEDs) in combat zones.

Aviation: Finally, KBCT plays a key role in the aviation industry. It provides customized solutions for aircraft control systems, maintenance management, and flight training simulators. These offerings enhance safety and efficiency while reducing costs and downtime in operations at airports and other flying facilities worldwide

The Endeavour Awards are a set of annual British awards which honour and recognize innovation, entrepreneurship and high-growth potential in European and British-based companies. The Awards, founded in 2009, are presented to ten companies which show exceptional promise for future success in various industries, including technology, healthcare, clean energy, and consumer goods.

Eligible companies must have been founded within the previous five years, have a core operations base in Europe or the United Kingdom, and demonstrate exceptional innovation, leadership, and potential for growth in their respective fields. The Awards are presented in three categories: The early-stage company, the high-growth company, and the sector-specific company.

The early-stage company award is given to companies which are in their early stages of development but have already shown significant promise in their respective markets. The high-growth company award is presented to companies which have experienced significant growth in recent years and have demonstrated a strong potential for continued growth and success. Finally, the sector-specific award is given to companies which have shown innovation and potential in specific industries, such as technology or clean energy.

In addition to the awards, the Endeavour Awards also provide beneficiaries with a range of resources and support, including mentorship, networking opportunities, and access to investors and potential customers. The Awards are an important platform for recognizing and supporting innovative companies in the UK and Europe, and have played a vital role in launching many successful businesses.

Overall, the Endeavour Awards continue to be a valuable resource for entrepreneurs, investors, and industry leaders seeking to identify and support the most promising companies in the UK and Europe. By celebrating and rewarding innovation, entrepreneurship, and potential, the Endeavour Awards play an important role in fostering a culture of growth and success in the British and European business communities.

The Bridgeport Traction Company was an electric railway company that operated in Connecticut from 1890 to 1927. It was founded by Charles H. Stetson, who had previously been involved with the New York and Lake Erie Railroad.

The company began operations on July 1, 1890, with a line running between Bridgeport and Stratford. In 1893, it extended its line northward to Milford, and in 1894 it built a branch line to Fairfield. At its peak, the Bridgeport Traction Company operated over 50 miles (80 km) of track.

In addition to passenger service, the company also provided freight transportation for various industries in the area, including steel mills, factories, and shipyards. However, as automobiles became more popular and competition from other railroads increased, the demand for electric railways declined.

By the early 1920s, the Bridgeport Traction Company was struggling financially. On January 1, 1927, it merged with the Danbury and Norwalk Railway, which had recently acquired the former New York and Lake Erie Railroad lines in the area. This merger effectively ended the independent existence of the Bridgeport Traction Company.

The Nakajima Ki-87, also known as the "Nakajima Night Fighter", was a single-seat, twin-engine night fighter aircraft developed by the Japanese aircraft manufacturer Nakajima during World War II. It was designed to replace the Ki-43 "Thunderbolt" in the Imperial Japanese Army Air Force's (IJAAF) night fighter fleet.

The Ki-87 was first flown on August 11, 1944, and entered service with the IJAAF in early 1945. It was primarily used in the defense of the Japanese homeland against nighttime air raids by the United States Army Air Forces (USAAF). The aircraft was also used in limited numbers by the Japanese Navy and the Imperial Japanese Marine Corps.

The Ki-87 was a heavily armed night fighter, equipped with two 20mm cannons and two 37mm cannons. It had a top speed of 630 km/h (390 mph) and a range of 1,100 km (680 mi). The aircraft had a maximum takeoff weight of 12,000 kg (26,400 lb) and a length of 10.5 meters (34 ft 10 in).

Despite its impressive armament and performance, the Ki-87 was not a successful aircraft. It was plagued by problems with its engines and transmission, and its heavy weight made it difficult to maneuver in combat. The aircraft was also vulnerable to attack by USAAF fighter aircraft, which were able to outmaneuver and outgun the Ki-87.

The Ki-87 was produced in small numbers, with a total of only 114 aircraft built. It was withdrawn from service with the IJAAF in early 1945, and was not replaced by any other night fighter.

Today, the Ki-87 is a rare and highly sought-after aircraft among collectors and enthusiasts. Only a few examples of the aircraft survive, and they are displayed in museums around the world.

Paul Scholes (born 16 November 1970) is an English former professional footballer who played as a midfielder. He is widely regarded as one of the greatest players in the history of Manchester United and the Premier League, with whom he won numerous domestic titles and Champions League trophies during his career.

Scholes began his playing career at Bradford City before joining Manchester United in 1993 for 4.75 million, where he went on to make over 600 appearances and score 128 goals for the club. During his time at Old Trafford, he became known for his passing ability, vision, and goal-scoring prowess from set pieces.

In addition to his successes at Manchester United, Scholes also had a successful international career with England, representing the national team between 1993 and 2004. He earned 34 caps and scored three goals for England, including a memorable strike against Argentina in the 1998 FIFA World Cup quarterfinal match.

After retiring from playing in 2004, Scholes turned to coaching and management. He spent several years working as an assistant manager at Manchester United under Sir Alex Ferguson before taking up the role of head coach at Sunderland in 2009. However, after just six months in charge, Scholes was sacked following poor results.

Since then, Scholes has worked as a pundit for various television channels, including Sky Sports and BT Sport. In 2013, he was inducted into the English Football Hall of Fame.

A rap superstar is an individual who has achieved significant fame and success in the hip hop music industry. These artists are known for their skillful rapping, charisma, and ability to connect with audiences through their music.

One of the most successful rap superstars of all time is Eminem. Born Marshall Mathers III on October 15, 1972, he began his career as a rapper at a young age. He rose to prominence in the early 2000s with his hit singles "Lose Yourself" and "The Real Slim Shady," which helped him become one of the best-selling rappers of all time.

Another iconic rap superstar is Jay-Z. Born Shawn Carter on December 4, 1968, he started out as a drug dealer before turning to music. He became one of the biggest names in hip hop in the late 1990s and early 2000s, with hits like "Hard Knock Life" and "Empire State of Mind."

Kanye West is another highly influential rap superstar. Born Kanye Omari West on June 8, 1973, he first gained attention as a producer for other artists before launching his own solo career. His innovative approach to hip hop and use of unconventional samples have made him one of the most celebrated producers and rappers of all time.

Nicki Minaj is also considered a rap superstar. Born Tracy Ann Williams on November 8, 1982, she rose to fame through her work as a mixtape artist and collaborator with other rappers. She later released several critically acclaimed albums and won numerous awards for her music.

These are just a few examples of the many talented rap superstars that have emerged over the years. Each of these artists has left a lasting impact on the hip hop industry and continues to inspire new generations of musicians.

Made-to-measure (MTM) is a term used in the clothing industry to describe a custom-made garment that is made to fit an individual's specific measurements. This type of garment is typically made to order, with the customer providing their measurements to the manufacturer or tailor, who then creates a garment that is specifically tailored to fit the customer's body.

Made-to-measure garments are often considered to be of higher quality than ready-to-wear clothing, as they are made to fit the individual perfectly. This can result in a more flattering and comfortable garment, as well as one that is more likely to last longer.

In the past, made-to-measure clothing was primarily available to the wealthy and elite, as it was a time-consuming and expensive process. However, with the advent of modern technology and mass production methods, made-to-measure clothing has become more accessible and affordable to a wider range of people.

Today, many clothing retailers offer made-to-measure services, either in-house or through partnerships with tailors. Customers can typically choose from a variety of styles and fabrics, and can also request specific details such as button placement or pocket placement.

In addition to clothing, made-to-measure services are also available for other types of garments, such as suits, dresses, and even shoes.

Overall, made-to-measure clothing is a popular choice for those who want a garment that is tailored to their specific needs and preferences. With the increasing availability and affordability of made-to-measure services, this type of custom-made garment is now within reach for many people.

Jazeera Airways is a Qatari low-cost airline based in Doha, Qatar. It was founded in 1992 and began operations in 1993. The airline is owned by the state of Qatar and is headquartered at Hamad International Airport.

Jazeera operates a fleet of modern aircraft, including the Airbus A320 and Boeing 787, and has a destinations network that spans the Middle East, North Africa, and Europe. The airline is known for its distinctive purple and green livery, which reflects the colors of the Qatari national flag.

Jazeera has been recognized for its safety and efficiency by various industry organizations, including the International Air Transport Association (IATA) and the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO). In addition, the airline has been praised for its commitment to environmental sustainability and has implemented a number of initiatives to reduce its carbon footprint.

Throughout its history, Jazeera has made significant contributions to the development of the aviation industry in Qatar and the region. The airline has played a key role in promoting tourism and business activity, and has been instrumental in connecting Qatar with the rest of the world.

Shelly Burch (born January 12, 1953) is an American author, journalist, and broadcaster. Burch studied for three months at the Moscow State University before returning to the United States with a backpack and $50 and enrolled in the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism, where she received her master's degree in broadcasting journalism.

In 1982, Burch joined the news team of 48 Hours (CBS), with veteran investigative journalist Ed Bradley, and together they reported on the 1981 CIA drug trafficking scandal known as Operation Bluebird. This was a major part of the series "CIA Files", and their investigation resulted in the resignation of CIA Director William Casey and the indictment of several high-ranking members of the agency.

Burch was nominated for five Emmy Awards for her work on 48 Hours, winning one for the reportage on drug trafficking from the U.S. border to American children. She went on to become a producer and correspondent for 60 Minutes II.

Burch's book, Investigating the Unexplained (1993) explores conspiracy theories and unsolved mysteries. It includes her investigative reports on the assassination of President John F. Kennedy, the CIA's involvement with drug trafficking, and the Mafia. She went on to write several other books and reports, including a series for National Public Radio called "The Mafia Files".

Burch is also an accomplished horsewoman and has run several marathons. She resides in Washington D.C. with her daughter, actress Katherine Burch.

Dave Ricketts is an American businessman and sports executive. He is the co-founder and executive chairman of TrueCar, an online automobile pricing and information platform. He is also the founder, CEO, and majority owner of the Los Angeles Dodgers baseball team.

Ricketts was born in Chattanooga, Tennessee. After graduating from Colgate University and earning a master's degree from Stanford University, he began his career in the finance industry, working at Goldman Sachs for seven years. During that time, he made a fortune investing in dot-com companies as part of his Silicon Valley Fund, which he founded in 1999.

In 2004, Ricketts joined the Dodger organization as vice chairman and assumed the role of president and CEO of TrueCar in 2012. Under his leadership, TrueCar became a leading online car shopping platform, providing consumers with up-front pricing for new and used cars.

In addition to his work with TrueCar, Ricketts is also a well-known sports enthusiast. In 2012, he purchased the Los Angeles Dodgers along with Mark Walter and Guggenheim Partners for $4.7 billion, the most ever paid for a sports team in North America. Ricketts and Dodgers ownership have since focused on building a competitive and successful team for the 2021 World Series, where they made it to the National League Championship Series.

Outside of sports and business, Ricketts is known for his philanthropy, particularly his support of education. He has supported several local education initiatives, including the Los Angeles County Office of Education and the Los Angeles Unified School District. He has also served on the Board of Directors for the Aspen Institute and the University of Chattanooga Foundation.

Garbage is an alternative rock band formed in Edinburgh, Scotland in 1987 by Shirley Manson and Mark Ronson. Over their career, they have released six studio albums, sold over 20 million records worldwide, and played to audiences around the globe.

Manson and Ronson had both been playing music for several years before forming Garbage. Manson was a vocalist with various bands in Edinburgh, while Ronson was a teacher of English as a foreign language at Heriot-Watt University. They first met when they were paired together for a duet performance at open mic night at Cowcaddens Bar in Edinburgh in 1985. Manson and Ronson later decided to form a new band. They initially called themselves Black Box but this name was already taken by another group in New York City. They then settled on the name Garbage after discovering that it was not in use by any other band at that time.

Garbage's debut album, also named Garbage, was recorded over nine months between November 1986 and August 1987 in Cannon Studios in East Kilbride, Glasgow, Scotland. The band spent most of their time writing songs, experimenting with different sounds and recording demos. After recording the album, Garbage went on to gain a record deal with EMI Records and began touring extensively throughout Europe in support of their album. Their second studio album, Popcorn Wars, was released in 1993, followed by Stupidity in 1994, Version 2.0 in Garbage

The Sanjak of Rhodes (Ottoman Turkish:  sjak) was an administrative unit of the Ottoman Empire in the eastern Mediterranean region, centered on the island of Rhodes. It was established in 1424, after the Ottoman conquest of the Kingdom of Cyprus, and existed until 1912, when it was dissolved as part of the reforms of the Young Turks. During its existence, the Sanjak of Rhodes was responsible for the administration of several territories, including parts of Greece, Cyprus, and Palestine.

During the early years of its existence, the Sanjak of Rhodes was ruled by a pasha, who was appointed by the sultan. The pasha had significant autonomy in the administration of the sanjak, and was responsible for collecting taxes, maintaining law and order, and overseeing public works projects. The pasha was also responsible for maintaining the fortifications of the island, which were crucial for the protection of the Ottoman Empire against foreign threats.

In the 17th century, the Sanjak of Rhodes experienced a decline in power, as the Ottoman Empire shifted its focus to the west and the navy became increasingly important. The pasha's power was further eroded by the increasing influence of the Ottoman central government in Istanbul, which began to impose more control over the provinces.

Despite its decline, the Sanjak of Rhodes remained an important cultural and economic center, particularly during the period of the Ottoman Renaissance. The island was home to a thriving Jewish community, and was a center of scholarship and culture, particularly in the fields of mathematics and astronomy.

In the 19th century, the Sanjak of Rhodes came under renewed attack from foreign powers, particularly France and Great Britain, which sought to gain control of the region as part of their imperialist ambitions. The Ottoman central government responded by reinforcing the fortifications of the island and increasing its military presence in the region.

However, the sanjak's efforts to resist foreign encroachment were ultimately futile, and in 1912 it was dissolved as part of the Ottoman Empire's reform

Bengt Bedrup (born 1952) is a Danish politician and former member of the Folketing, representing the Social Democrats. He was born in Copenhagen on 30 January 1952 to parents Ole and Inge Bedrup.

Bedrup studied at the University of Copenhagen, where he earned his master's degree in political science in 1978. After completing his studies, he worked as an assistant for several years before becoming a full-time employee of the Social Democratic Party.

In 1994, Bedrup was elected to the Folketing for the first time, representing the constituency of Frederiksberg. During his time in parliament, he served as chairman of the Committee on Foreign Policy from 2006 to 2009.

Prior to his election to the Folketing, Bedrup had been active in local politics in Frederiksberg Municipality, serving as mayor from 1990 to 1994.

Bedrup has also held various leadership positions within the Social Democratic Party, including serving as vice chairman of the party's national executive committee from 2002 to 2005.

Outside of politics, Bedrup has been involved in several non-profit organizations focused on international development and humanitarian aid. He has traveled extensively throughout Africa and Asia, working with organizations such as UNICEF and Doctors Without Borders.

The Kalash Criminel (also known as the Kalashnikov Criminal) is a term used to describe a type of criminal in Russia and other post-Soviet states who is known for using Kalashnikov assault rifles in their crimes. The term is often used to describe organized crime groups, such as the Russian Mafia, who use the weapons for intimidation, assassination, and other criminal activities.

The Kalashnikov Criminel is often associated with the use of the AK-47, a type of assault rifle that was developed by Mikhail Kalashnikov in the 1940s. The weapon is known for its reliability, durability, and ease of use, making it a popular choice among criminals.

The use of Kalashnikovs in criminal activities has become a significant problem in Russia and other post-Soviet states. RTP1 (Real Time Protocol 1) is an open-source protocol for real-time communication over IP networks. It was developed by the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) and published as IETF Request for Comments (RFC) 4580 in October 2006.

RTP1 provides reliable, ordered delivery of data packets between two or more endpoints on an IP network. It uses a combination of packet retransmission and congestion control to ensure that data is delivered with low latency and high reliability.

One key feature of RTP1 is its support for multiple media types, including audio, video, and text. This allows it to be used for a wide range of applications, from simple voice calls to complex multimedia streaming systems.

In addition to providing reliable data transmission, RTP1 also includes features such as synchronization of playback across multiple streams, and support for metadata associated with each stream. These features make it well suited for use in multimedia environments where precise timing and synchronization are critical.

Overall, RTP1 is an important standard for real-time communication over IP networks. Its widespread adoption has made it a key component of many modern multimedia systems, and its ongoing development continues to improve its capabilities and performance.

Jackson Heights is a neighborhood in the Queens borough of New York City, United States. Located in northern Queens, it is largely inhabited by Hispanic and Asian residents. As of the 2010 United States Census, the population of Jackson Heights was 370,367, an increase of 22% from the 308,745 recorded in 2000. It is the most populous neighborhood in Queens, and one of the most densely populated areas in the United States. 

Jackson Heights is named after Andrew Jackson, the 7th President of the United States, and is one of several communities in the New York City metropolitan area named after him. It is also home to the headquarters of the United Nations General Assembly.

The neighborhood has a diverse range of architecture, including Art Deco, International Style, and Tudor Revival. It is known for its sidewalks, which are filled with outdoor cafes, street vendors, and shops serving ethnic cuisine. 

Community residents have advocated for greater access to public transit and affordable housing, which have become pressing issues in recent years. The neighborhood is served by several subway lines: the 7, 65, and Q trains. The area also has extensive bus service, with more than two dozen bus routes serving the neighborhood.

The public school system in Jackson Heights is operated by the New York City Department of Education. It serves nearly 60,000 students in more than 350 schools throughout the borough. 

Many famous people have ties to Jackson Heights, including actor and comedian Eddie Murphy, who was born in the neighborhood, and actress Sarah Jessica Parker, who grew up there. It is also home to the Jewish Center for Community Development and Learning, as well as several synagogues and other places of worship.

Overall, Jackson Heights is a vibrant and diverse neighborhood in Queens, known for its unique culture and history.
